questions.text: Identify the vitamin deficiency: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin D

 

Vitamin D The image show Bowing of the legs, a condition known as bowlegs or genu varum, is commonly associated with Vitamin D deficiency, especially in children. Vitamin D plays a crucial role in the regulation of calcium and phosphorus, essential minerals for bone health. Deficiency of Vitamin D can lead to improper mineralization of bones, resulting in deformities such as bowing of the legs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency is not typically associated with bowing of the legs. However, severe vitamin A deficiency cause night blindness and other eye menifestations.

 

Option C. Vitamin B3 (Niacin): Vitamin B3 deficiency can cause pellagra, which involves skin, gastrointestinal, and neurological symptoms. It is not directly linked to bowing of the legs.

 

Option D. Vitamin B1 (Thiamine): Vitamin B1 deficiency can lead to beriberi, a condition that primarily affects the cardiovascular and nervous systems. It is not a common cause of bowing of the legs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin D

questions.text: Match the following disorders with their respective clinical features or lab findings: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 → A, 2 → C, 3 → B, 4 → D

 

The matching of disorders with their respective clinical features or lab findings is based on the specific enzymatic defects associated with each type of glycogen storage disease (GSD).

 

  1. Cori’s Disease (Type III GSD):
    • Correct Match: A. Branched structure in liver biopsy
    • In Cori’s disease, the deficiency of the debranching enzyme leads to the accumulation of abnormal glycogen with short outer branches, often referred to as "limit dextrin." This structural abnormality can be observed in a liver biopsy.
       
  2. McArdle’s Disease (Type V GSD):
    • Correct Match: C. Exercise intolerance
    • McArdle’s disease is caused by a deficiency in muscle phosphorylase (myophosphorylase), which is required for glycogen breakdown in muscle tissue. As a result, individuals with McArdle’s disease experience exercise intolerance due to the inability to produce adequate energy during physical activity.
       
  3. Pompe’s Disease (Type II GSD):
    • Correct Match: B. Accumulation of glycogen in lysosome
    • Pompe’s disease is characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme acid maltase (alpha-glucosidase), which leads to the accumulation of glycogen in lysosomes. This condition is also classified as a lysosomal storage disease.
       
  4. Von Gierke’s Disease (Type I GSD):
    • Correct Match: D. Hypoglycemia with lactic acidosis
    • Von Gierke’s disease results from a deficiency in glucose-6-phosphatase, an enzyme critical for gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis. The lack of this enzyme leads to severe fasting hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, and hepatomegaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycogen storage diseases (GSDs) are classified based on the specific enzyme deficiency involved, leading to distinct clinical features such as exercise intolerance in McArdle’s disease, glycogen accumulation in lysosomes in Pompe’s disease, and hypoglycemia with lactic acidosis in Von Gierke’s disease.

choices.text: It has a higher mutation rate than nuclear DNA
It codes for more than 25% of oxidative phosphorylation proteins

questions.text: True regarding Mitochondrial DNA is? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It has a higher mutation rate than nuclear DNA

 

Mitochondrial DNA and RNA

 

  1. There is a dichotomy on the mitochondrial metabolism. Some of the mitochondrial protein synthesis is under the control of mitochondrial DNA; but important proteins of the outer membrane of the mitochondria are synthesized under the influence of nuclear DNA.
  2. The mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is circular, has about 16,500 nucleotides. The mtDNA has information for synthesis of 2 ribosomal RNAs, 22 tRNAs and 13 proteins. All of them are components of electron transport chain. It has 37 genes that encode 13 protein subunits of the respiratory chain (total of 67 i.e., about 20%). However, most of mitochondrial proteins are encoded by nuclear DNA and synthesized in the cytoplasm.
  3. Maternal inheritance: Since, the mitochondria are inherited cytoplasmically, the mtDNA is inherited from the mother. Mother transmits mtDNA through oocyte.
  4. There are hundreds of copies of mtDNA in each cell (nuclear DNA has only 2 copies).
  5. Heteroplasmy is defined as the presence of normal and mutant mtDNA in different proportions in different cells. During cell division, mtDNA replicates and they segregate to the daughter cells. If a mutation occurs in mtDNA, the daughter cells may inherit the mutant or normal mtDNA.
  6. High mutation rate: 5-10 times that of nuclear DNA
  7. Age-related accumulation of mutations in mtDNA may be responsible for age-related decrease in cellular OXPHOS function, and progression of other degenerative diseases.
  8. Defects in mitochondrial genome will lead to mitochondrial myopathies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. One set from each parent: Incorrect. mtDNA is inherited only from the mother.

 

Option C. It codes for more than 25% of oxidative phosphorylation proteins: Incorrect. mtDNA encodes about 13 protein subunits of the respiratory chain, approximately 20% of the total, not more than 25%.

 

Option D. It has 3 X 10^9 base pairs: Incorrect. mtDNA is much smaller, with about 16,500 base pairs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitochondrial DNA has a higher mutation rate than nuclear DNA, is maternally inherited, and contains 37 genes encoding essential components of the electron transport chain.

 

Ref - Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students 7th edition

questions.text: A paint factory worker working since 20 years complains of joint pain, insomnia, fatigue, constipation, headache. He is found to have anemia. Enzyme affected is? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ferrochelatase

 

This enzyme is crucial in the final step of heme synthesis, where it inserts iron into protoporphyrin to form heme. In lead poisoning, ferrochelatase is inhibited, leading to decreased heme production, increased ALA production, and symptoms such as anemia, fatigue, and other neurological symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uroporphyrinogen III synthase: This enzyme is involved in heme synthesis. Lead poisoning can disrupt heme synthesis, but Uroporphyrinogen III synthase is not the primary enzyme affected.

 

Option B. Uroporphyrinogen I Synthase: Similar to Uroporphyrinogen III synthase, this enzyme is involved in heme synthesis. Lead poisoning can disrupt heme synthesis, but Uroporphyrinogen I Synthase is not the primary enzyme affected.

 

Option C. ALA synthase (Aminolevulinic acid synthase): It is a key enzyme in the heme synthesis pathway. Lead poisoning increase activity of ALA synthase. In lead poisoning, product inhibition by heme is  reduced leading to the accumulation of ALA and its precursor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The reference of paint factory worker indicates that it is a case of lead poisoning. Lead affects two enzymes of Heme synthesis pathway:

 

  1. PBG synthase (another name ALA dehydratase)
  2. Ferrochelatase (last enzyme of heme synthesis and adds Fe to its substrate)

 

The defect in any of these enzymes will lead to decrease in haem synthesis resulting in anemia. So, the answer in this case is Ferrochelatase.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 306-307

choices.text: DNA replication errors

questions.text: A researcher is studying the impact of environmental factors on gene expression in a group of identical twins who have developed different traits despite having the same DNA sequence. The study focuses on how certain chemical modifications can regulate gene activity without altering the underlying genetic code. Which of the following mechanisms is responsible for altering gene expression through methylation and acetylation without changing the gene sequence?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Epigenetics

 

Explanation:

 

Epigenetics is the study of heritable changes in gene expression that do not involve changes to the underlying DNA sequence. This involves mechanisms like DNA methylation, which adds a methyl group to DNA, usually at cytosine residues in CpG islands, leading to gene silencing, and histone acetylation, which loosens the chromatin structure, allowing transcription factors access to the DNA, thus promoting gene expression. These modifications can turn genes on or off without altering the DNA sequence itself and can be influenced by environmental factors, making epigenetics a key area in understanding gene regulation.

 

Other Options:

 

A. Genetic mutation: Genetic mutations involve permanent changes in the DNA sequence, such as point mutations, deletions, or insertions, which can affect gene function. Unlike epigenetics, mutations directly alter the genetic code and are not reversible or influenced by methylation and acetylation.

 

C. DNA replication errors: Errors during DNA replication can lead to changes in the DNA sequence, such as mismatched bases or strand slippage, potentially resulting in mutations. These errors directly change the DNA sequence and do not involve the reversible regulatory mechanisms seen in epigenetics.

 

D. Chromosomal translocation: Chromosomal translocation involves the rearrangement of parts between nonhomologous chromosomes, which can disrupt gene function or create new gene fusions. This process affects the physical structure of chromosomes rather than altering gene expression through methylation or acetylation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epigenetics refers to heritable changes in gene expression that occur without altering the DNA sequence, primarily through mechanisms such as DNA methylation and histone acetylation. These modifications influence how genes are activated or silenced, making epigenetics a critical component in gene regulation, development, and the response to environmental factors. Understanding these processes helps explain why identical genetic codes can lead to different phenotypic outcomes.

questions.text: Which amino acid is not used for synthesis of hormones?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glycine

 

Glycine is an amino acid that does not directly participate in the synthesis of hormones. While glycine is an important amino acid involved in many biological processes, including the synthesis of proteins, it is not a precursor for hormone synthesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tyrosine: Tyrosine is a precursor for the synthesis of several important hormones, including thyroid hormones (thyroxine and triiodothyronine), catecholamines (epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dopamine), and melanin.

 

Option B. Phenylalanine: Phenylalanine is converted into tyrosine in the body and, as a result, indirectly contributes to hormone synthesis. Tyrosine, derived from phenylalanine, is then used for the synthesis of various hormones.

 

Option C. Tryptophan: Tryptophan is an essential amino acid that serves as a precursor for the synthesis of serotonin and melatonin, both of which are important hormones involved in regulating mood, sleep, and other physiological processes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tyrosine, phenylalanine, and tryptophan are all aromatic amino acids that serve as building blocks for the synthesis of various hormones.

questions.text: Alkali disease of livestock is caused by an excess of which of the following minerals? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Selenium

 

Animals that consume grains containing 5 to 40 mg selenium/kg over a period of several weeks or months suffer from chronic selenosis, known as alkali disease. Signs include liver cirrhosis, lameness, hoof malformations, loss of hair, and emaciation.

 

 It is associated with loss of hair on the mane and tail, hoof deformities, and decreased reproductive performance1. It is caused by toxicity from eating plants or grain with protein-bound, insoluble selenium2. This disease normally occurs in cattle and sheep feeding on seleniferous plants

 

Selenium intoxication can also be acute and subacute (blind staggers type).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Manganese:

  • Deficiency: Manganese deficiency can lead to skeletal abnormalities, reproductive issues, and poor growth in livestock.
  • Excess: Excess manganese is rare and typically does not cause a condition similar to alkali disease.

 

Option C. Molybdenum:

  • Deficiency: Molybdenum deficiency can impair the function of molybdoenzymes, leading to metabolic disturbances.
  • Excess: Excess molybdenum can interfere with copper metabolism, leading to copper deficiency (known as molybdenosis) in livestock, characterized by symptoms such as diarrhea, poor growth, and anemia.

 

Option D. Iron:

  • Deficiency: Iron deficiency can lead to anemia, weakness, and poor growth in livestock.
  • Excess: Excess iron can cause toxicity, but it does not cause the specific symptoms of alkali disease. Iron toxicity is more likely to result in gastrointestinal disturbances and liver damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alkali disease in livestock is caused by chronic selenium toxicity, leading to liver cirrhosis, hoof malformations, loss of hair, and emaciation. This condition is distinct from the effects of other mineral toxicities or deficiencies.

questions.text: Entry of glucose is insulin independent in all of them except: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Answer: C. Adipose tissues

 

Glucose enters cells through GLUT (glucose transporter) proteins. Some are insulin-dependent, while others are not.

 

Adipose tissues:
•    Use GLUT4
•    Insulin-dependent
•    Insulin stimulates translocation of GLUT4 to membrane → increases glucose uptake

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. RBC (Red Blood Cells)
•    Use GLUT1
•    Insulin-independent

 

Option B. Pancreas (β-cells)
•    Use GLUT2
•    Insulin-independent
•    Glucose entry triggers insulin secretion

 

Option D. Brain
•    Uses GLUT1 (BBB) and GLUT3 (neurons)
•    Both are insulin-independent
•    Brain requires a constant glucose supply regardless of insulin


 

Educational Objective:

 

Major Glucose transporters and their function is summarized as:

questions.text: Ammonia in the brain is detoxified to form? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glutamine

 

First Line of Defense (Trapping of Ammonia) - Being highly toxic, ammonia should be eliminated or detoxified, as and when it is formed. Even very minute quantity of ammonia may produce toxicity in central nervous system. But, ammonia is always produced by almost all cells, including neurons. The intracellular ammonia is immediately trapped by glutamic acid to form glutamine, especially in brain cells. The glutamine is then transported to liver, where the reaction is reversed by the enzyme glutaminase. The ammonia thus generated is immediately detoxified into urea. Aspartic acid may also undergo similar reaction to form asparagine.

 

 

Ammonia trapping as glutamine

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Urea: Urea is the primary form of nitrogen excretion in the liver, but it is not the form in which ammonia is detoxified in the brain.

 

Option C. Ammonium ions: Ammonium ions can be a form of ammonia detoxification in the kidney, but not the primary method in the brain.

 

Option D. Alanine: Alanine plays a role in transporting ammonia from muscle to the liver, but it is not the primary detoxification product in the brain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the brain, ammonia is detoxified by converting it to glutamine, which is then transported to the liver for further detoxification into urea.

questions.text: Deficiency of which of the following causes increased glutamine in blood? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ornithine transcarbamoylase

 

Deficiency of ornithine transcarbamoylase is an X-linked genetic disorder known as ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency (OTC deficiency). This deficiency impairs the urea cycle's function, leading to the accumulation of ammonia and causing hyperammonemia. Elevated ammonia levels can indirectly affect glutamine metabolism, potentially leading to increased glutamine in the blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arginosuccinate lyase: Deficiency of arginosuccinate lyase is associated with argininosuccinic aciduria, a disorder that results in the accumulation of argininosuccinic acid and ammonia. However, this deficiency does not directly lead to increased glutamine levels.

 

Option B. Alpha-galactosidase-A: Deficiency of alpha-galactosidase-A is associated with Fabry disease, a lysosomal storage disorder. It does not lead to increased glutamine levels in the blood.

 

Option D. Arginase: Deficiency of arginase is associated with argininemia, a rare urea cycle disorder. Arginase deficiency leads to the accumulation of arginine and ammonia in the blood. As with OTC deficiency, elevated ammonia levels can indirectly affect glutamine metabolism, potentially leading to increased glutamine in the blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ornithine transcarbamoylase deficiency is a urea cycle disorder, which is inherited as an X-linked trait. Hyperammonemia Type II is characterized by OTC deficiency. Mothers also have hyperammonemia and an aversion to high protein diet. To reduce ammonia levels, glutamate combines with ammonia to form glutamine. Thus, elevated levels of ammonia are associated with high glutamine levels in CSF and blood.

 

Urea cycle disorders

questions.text: Uracil was found in genetic code. Which vitamin deficiency leads to this condition:(INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Folate

 

  • Folate deficiency is the correct answer. Folate (also known as vitamin B9) plays a crucial role in DNA synthesis and repair. When there is a deficiency in folate, it can lead to the misincorporation of Uracil into DNA, causing DNA instability and other genetic abnormalities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. B12: A deficiency in vitamin B12 is not directly associated with the presence of Uracil in the genetic code. Vitamin B12 deficiency primarily affects red blood cell production and neurological functions.

 

Option B. B6: A deficiency in vitamin B6 is also not directly related to the presence of Uracil in the genetic code. Vitamin B6 deficiency can lead to various neurological symptoms but does not cause Uracil incorporation into DNA.

 

Option D. Vit E: Vitamin E deficiency does not lead to the presence of Uracil in the genetic code. Vitamin E is primarily known for its antioxidant properties and its role in maintaining cell membranes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Genetic code is related to DNA, but DNA do not contain Uracil. In pyrimidine synthesis, UMP is the first pyrimidine nucleotide to be synthesized and other two pyrimidines thymine and Cytosine are synthesized from it. Uracil to cytosine conversion requires amino group addition provided by glutamine. Uracil is converted to thymine by enzyme thymidylate synthase by methylation where methyl group is donated by methyl-THF. So, a deficiency Folate will result in thymine deficiency and may lead to uracil appearing in the DNA in place of thymine.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 333

questions.text: Child presents with hypotonia and seizures. It was confirmed to be Zellweger syndrome. Which among the following accumulates in brain in this condition? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Long chain fatty acid

 

Zellweger syndrome is due to defective oxidation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFA). Peroxisomal enzymes are produced; but their entry into peroxisome is denied. This leads to insufficient oxidation of VLCFA. Accumulation of VLCFA in CNS causes neurological impairment and death in childhood.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucose: Accumulation of glucose is associated with disorders like diabetes, not Zellweger syndrome.

 

Option B. Lactic acid: Accumulation of lactic acid is seen in lactic acidosis and mitochondrial disorders, but not specifically in Zellweger syndrome.

 

Option D. Triglycerides: While triglycerides are stored fats, their accumulation is not the primary issue in Zellweger syndrome. The critical problem is the accumulation of VLCFA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zellweger syndrome leads to the accumulation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFA) in the brain due to defective peroxisomal oxidation, resulting in severe neurological impairments and early childhood death.

questions.text: Brunt sugar smell of urine is due to the defect of? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Branched chain keto acid dehydrogenase

 

Explanation:

 

  • Burnt sugar-like odour is a characteristic feature of Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD) which occurs due to the inherited deficiency of branched chain Keto-acid dehydrogenase/decarboxylase.
  • It results in a defect in oxidative phosphorylation and catabolism of branched-chain amino acids (BCAA) Valine/Isoleucine/leucine. As a result, these amino acids are excreted in urine. There is also mental retardation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenylalanine hydroxylase: Deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase leads to phenylketonuria (PKU), which is characterized by a mousy or musty odor due to the accumulation of phenylalanine and its metabolites.

 

Option B. Isovaleryl CoA dehydrogenase: Deficiency of isovaleryl CoA dehydrogenase causes isovaleric acidemia, which is associated with a rancid, cheesy, or sweaty feet odor due to the accumulation of isovaleric acid.

 

Option C. Fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase: Deficiency of fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase leads to tyrosinemia type I, which is characterized by a boiled cabbage or rotten mushrooms odor due to the accumulation of tyrosine and its metabolites.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the Respiratory Quotient (RQ) of a person consuming a pure carbohydrate diet? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Answer: B. 1

 

Explanation:

 

The Respiratory Quotient (RQ) is the ratio of CO2 produced to O2 consumed. On a pure carbohydrate diet, carbohydrates are completely oxidized to CO2 and water, leading to an RQ of 1. This is because the amount of CO2 produced is equal to the amount of O2 consumed.

 

Other options:

  • A. 0.7: This RQ value is typical of a diet high in fats, which require more oxygen for oxidation compared to the carbon they yield as CO2.
  • C. 1.2 and D. 1.5: These values are not typical RQs for any standard macronutrient-based diet and could only be seen in pathological conditions or with substrates not typically found in a normal diet.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Respiratory Quotient (RQ) for a pure carbohydrate diet is 1, reflecting the equal molar consumption of O2 and production of CO2, which is characteristic of carbohydrate metabolism.

E1: Pyruvate Decarboxylase E2: Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase
E1: Pyruvate carboxylase E2: Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase

questions.text: This multienzyme complex converts Pyruvate to Acetyl CoA. Identify E1 and E2: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) E1: Pyruvate dehydrogenase E2: Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase

 

Explanation:

 

The provided images depict the components and functioning of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex, a key multienzyme complex in the metabolic pathway that converts pyruvate into acetyl-CoA, an essential step linking glycolysis to the citric acid cycle. This complex requires vitamins B1, B2, B3, B5, and lipoic acid as cofactors.

 

Table: Components of PDH complex and their roles

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pyruvate Decarboxylase and Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase: Incorrect as Pyruvate Decarboxylase is not involved in the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA in this context, and Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase is the E3 component of the complex.

 

Option C. Pyruvate carboxylase and Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase: Incorrect because Pyruvate carboxylase is involved in a different metabolic pathway (gluconeogenesis), not in the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA.

 

Option D. Pyruvate dehydrogenase and Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase: Incorrect as the second enzyme is E3 in this complex, not E2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 162

questions.text: Insulin inhibits which of the following lipase enzymes? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hormone sensitive lipase

 

Insulin inhibits hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL). Hormone-sensitive lipase is responsible for the breakdown of triglycerides stored in adipose tissue into fatty acids and glycerol. When insulin levels are high, such as after a meal, it promotes fat storage and inhibits HSL activity, reducing the release of fatty acids from adipose tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lipoprotein lipase: Insulin activates lipoprotein lipase (LPL). Lipoprotein lipase is an enzyme that plays a crucial role in the metabolism of lipoproteins, specifically in the hydrolysis of triglycerides in circulating chylomicrons and very low-density lipoproteins (VLDL). Insulin promotes LPL activity, which facilitates the uptake of fatty acids into adipose tissue and muscle for storage and energy utilization.

 

Option C. Acid lipase: Insulin does not have a direct inhibitory effect on acid lipase. Acid lipase enzymes, such as gastric lipase and lysosomal lipase, function in different environments and processes compared to the regulation of lipids by insulin in the bloodstream.

 

Option D. Alkaline lipase: Insulin does not have a direct inhibitory effect on alkaline lipase. Alkaline lipases are typically found in the pancreas and function in the digestion of dietary fats. They are not directly regulated by insulin in the same way as the lipases involved in adipose tissue and circulating lipoprotein metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Insulin is an anabolic hormone so activates anabolic enzymes and inhibits catabolic enzymes. Hormone sensitive lipase is a catabolic enzyme present in adipose tissue cells which causes release of fatty acids from stored TG during starvation. So, it is activated by catabolic enzyme Glucagon. Lipoprotein lipase on the other hand is an anabolic enzyme and release FA from TG of VLDL and chylomicrons in fed state. Understanding the regulatory role of insulin in lipase enzymes is essential for medical students. Insulin inhibits hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL) to promote fat storage and activates lipoprotein lipase (LPL) to facilitate fatty acid uptake, which helps maintain energy homeostasis and lipid metabolism in the body.

 

Ref- Harper 31st e/p 240, 245

questions.text: A bodybuilder starts eating raw eggs for protein. He starts to develop fatigue on moderate exercise. The doctor prescribes a vitamin. Which enzyme is deficient in him? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pyruvate Carboxylase

 

Raw eggs contain a protein called avidin, which binds to biotin and prevents its absorption in the intestine. Biotin is a vital coenzyme for several carboxylase enzymes, including pyruvate carboxylase. When biotin is deficient, these enzymes cannot function properly, leading to symptoms such as fatigue, particularly during moderate exercise.

 

Mechanism:

  • Avidin in Raw Eggs: Binds strongly to biotin, preventing its absorption and leading to biotin deficiency.
  • Pyruvate Carboxylase Deficiency: Results in impaired gluconeogenesis and energy production, causing fatigue during exercise.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucose 6 Phosphate:

  • Function: Involved in glycogenolysis and the pentose phosphate pathway.
  • Relevance: Not related to biotin deficiency or the symptoms described.

 

Option C. PEPCK (Phosphoenolpyruvate Carboxykinase):

  • Function: Catalyzes the conversion of oxaloacetate to phosphoenolpyruvate in gluconeogenesis.
  • Relevance: Although involved in gluconeogenesis, its activity is not directly dependent on biotin.

 

Option D. Glycogen Phosphorylase:

  • Function: Breaks down glycogen to glucose-1-phosphate in glycogenolysis.
  • Relevance: Not related to biotin deficiency or the symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eating raw eggs can lead to biotin deficiency due to avidin binding, resulting in a deficiency of pyruvate carboxylase. This enzyme deficiency impairs gluconeogenesis, causing fatigue during exercise. Supplementing biotin can correct the deficiency and alleviate symptoms.

questions.text: What is the repair mechanism associated with CRISPR-Cas9? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Non-homologous end joining

 

NHEJ is the primary repair mechanism associated with CRISPR-Cas9. When CRISPR-Cas9 induces double-strand breaks in DNA, NHEJ rejoins the broken DNA ends, often introducing insertions or deletions (indels) at the repair site. This can result in gene knockout or disruption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Base excision repair (BER): BER is a DNA repair mechanism that corrects damaged or mismatched bases in the DNA. It primarily deals with single-base changes and small DNA lesions. CRISPR-Cas9, on the other hand, creates double-strand breaks, so BER is not directly involved in repairing these breaks.

 

Option B. Nucleotide excision repair (NER): NER is another DNA repair mechanism that mainly deals with the removal of larger DNA lesions, such as those caused by UV radiation. It is not the primary repair mechanism associated with CRISPR-Cas9-induced double-strand breaks.

 

Option D. Mismatch repair (MMR): MMR is a repair mechanism that corrects errors in DNA replication, specifically base-pair mismatches and small insertion-deletion loops. It is not the primary mechanism involved in repairing double-strand breaks created by CRISPR-Cas9.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary repair mechanism associated with CRISPR-Cas9 is non-homologous end joining (NHEJ), which repairs double-strand breaks by ligating the broken DNA ends, potentially causing insertions or deletions that disrupt the target gene.

questions.text: Restriction endonuclease will act on which of the following? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) AAGCTT

 

Restriction endonucleases have specific recognition sites where they cut the DNA. These enzymes recognize specific sequence with palindrome arrangement. These are also called inverted repeat sequences, which means the nucleotide sequence in 5’ to 3’ direction is the same in both strands.

 

AAGCTT is a palindromic sequence and other 3 options are not palindromic sequence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: AAGAAG
•    Complement: 3′-TTCTTC5’ 
•    Not palindromic
•    Not recognized by any common restriction enzyme

 

Option B: GAGAGG
•    Complement: 3′-CTCTCC 5’
•    Not a palindrome
•    Not a restriction site

 

Option D: TACGAG
•    Complement: 3′-ATGCTC 5’
•    Not a palindrome
•    Not recognized by known restriction enzymes

 

Educational Objective:

 

Restriction endonucleases act and cleave at the site of a palindromic sequence, such as:

 

5' --AAGCTT-- 3'

3' --TTCGAA-- 5'
