questions.text: Which of the following enzymes has the highest catalytic efficiency? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Km of an enzyme = 2 micromole and Kcat = 200 per sec

 

Catalytic efficiency is calculated as Kcat/Km. Higher values of Kcat and lower values of Km gives better catalytic efficiency.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Catalytic efficiency, calculated as 𝐾𝑐𝑎𝑡/𝐾𝑚 is maximized with high 𝐾𝑐𝑎𝑡​ and low Km​.

questions.text: Replacing alanine by which amino acid, will increase UV absorbance of protein at 280nm wavelength? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tryptophan

 

Tryptophan due to presence of conjugated double bonds in phenyl group has a strong UV absorbance at 280 nm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Arginine: Arginine does not have a strong absorbance peak at 280 nm, so it would not significantly increase UV absorbance at this wavelength when substituted for alanine.

 

Option C. Guanine: Guanine is a nucleotide base found in DNA and RNA, but it is not an amino acid. It absorbs at 260 nm.

 

Option D. Lysine: Lysine, like arginine, does not have a strong absorbance peak at 280 nm and would not significantly increase UV absorbance when substituted for alanine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

UV absorption occur due to conjugated double bonds in the ring. So, to increase the UV absorbance of protein at 280nm, alanine should be replaced by any aromatic amino acids such as Phenylalanine, tyrosine and tryptophan. Out of these, tryptophan absorbs ultraviolet light about ten times more efficiently than either phenylalanine or tyrosine due to presence of two rings in its side chain compared to only one in other two amino acids.

 

All other amino acid given here do not absorb UV light due to lack of conjugated double bonds.

 

Guanine is nitrogenous base not amino acid. It absorbs at 260nm.

 

Additional information:

 

Absorbance of compounds:

 

  • Proteins - 280nm (Aromatic amino acids)
  • Nucleic acids - 260 nm (N-bases)
  • NADH/NADPH - 340 nm
  • Porphyrins - 400 nm (Soret band).

questions.text: The active site of enzyme is complimentary to: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Substrate

 

The active site of an enzyme is complementary to the substrate. The active site is a specific region of the enzyme where the substrate binds, forming an enzyme-substrate complex. This binding is highly specific and is often likened to a lock-and-key or induced-fit model. It provides a specific environment that facilitates the conversion of substrate into product.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transition state: The transition state refers to the intermediate state of a substrate as it undergoes a reaction and transforms into a product. While enzymes stabilize the transition state during catalysis, the active site itself is typically complementary to the substrate, not the transition state.

 

Option B. Allosteric activator: Allosteric activators bind to allosteric sites on enzymes, which are distinct from the active site. Allosteric regulation involves a change in the enzyme's conformation, affecting its activity.

 

Option D. Product: The active site is not complementary to the product. Once the reaction occurs, the product is released from the active site, allowing the enzyme to participate in another catalytic cycle with a new substrate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective here is to understand the concept of the active site of an enzyme and its relationship to substrates. The active site of an enzyme is complimentary to the substrate, allowing specific interactions that enable the enzyme to catalyze a particular chemical reaction. It stabilizes the transition state of the reaction, facilitating the conversion of substrates into products.

questions.text: What is the primary precursor in the synthesis of steroid hormones? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Pregnenolone

 

Explanation:

 

Pregnenolone serves as the foundational precursor in the synthesis of all steroid hormones. It is synthesized directly from cholesterol in the mitochondria of steroid-producing cells, such as those in the adrenal cortex and gonads. This transformation involves the cleavage of the cholesterol side chain, catalyzed by the enzyme cytochrome P450scc, making pregnenolone the first steroid formed in the steroidogenesis pathway. From pregnenolone, further enzymatic reactions lead to the production of various steroid hormones including glucocorticoids, mineralocorticoids, and sex steroids.

 

Other Options:

 

  • a. Cortisone: While a steroid hormone, cortisone is not a precursor but rather a downstream product in the steroidogenesis pathway.
  • b. 7-Dihydrocholesterol: This compound is primarily involved in the synthesis of vitamin D3, not directly in the synthesis of steroid hormones.
  • c. 7-Hydroxycholesterol: Like 7-dihydrocholesterol, this is not a direct precursor in the synthesis of steroid hormones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pregnenolone is the initial steroid synthesized from cholesterol and serves as the precursor for all other steroid hormones.

questions.text: The significance of HMP shunt are all except? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Utilizes ribose

 

Explanation:

 

The Hexose Monophosphate (HMP) shunt, also known as the pentose phosphate pathway (PPP), has several significant roles:

 

Option A. Source of NADPH: The HMP shunt produces NADPH in its oxidative phase. NADPH is essential for various biosynthetic reactions, including fatty acid synthesis and maintaining the reduced state of glutathione in red blood cells.

 

Option B. Source of ribose 5 phosphate: At the end of the oxidative phase, ribulose 5-phosphate is produced, which can be further converted into ribose 5-phosphate. Ribose 5-phosphate is a crucial precursor for the synthesis of nucleotides and nucleic acids.

 

Option C. Source of acetyl CoA: One of the end products of the HMP shunt is glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate, which can enter glycolysis. Through glycolysis, it can eventually form pyruvate, which can be converted into acetyl CoA in the presence of oxygen.

 

Option D. Utilizes ribose: This statement is incorrect as the HMP shunt primarily produces ribose 5-phosphate rather than utilizing it. Ribose 5-phosphate is a significant product of this pathway and is used in the synthesis of nucleotides and nucleic acids.

 

The overall reaction of the HMP shunt can be summarized as:

 

3G-6-P+6NADP+→2G-6-P+Glyceraldehyde-3-P+3CO2+6NADPH

 

Educational Objective:

 

The HMP shunt is significant for producing NADPH and ribose 5-phosphate and indirectly contributing to the formation of acetyl CoA, but it does not utilize ribose.

questions.text: A patient has a blood glucose level of 200 mg/dL and GFR of 90 ml/min. What is the amount of glucose excreted if the transport maximum of the patient is as shown below? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 30 mg/min

 

The amount of glucose excreted in the above scenario is 30 mg/min.

 

Calculation:

 

Step 1: Total filtered glucose calculated by GFR x Plasma glucose concentration

Here,

 

  • ﻿﻿GFR = 90 ml/min
  • ﻿﻿Plasma glucose concentration = 200 mg/dL= 2 mg/ml (1 dL=100 ml).
  • ﻿﻿Total filtered glucose = 90 ml/min X 2 mg/ml = 180 mg/min.

 

Step 2: Check transport maximum:

Here, as shown in the graph transport maximum is 150 mg/min.

 

Step 3: Calculate the excretion

 

  • Excretion = Total filtered glucose - Total reabsorbed glucose (Transport Maximum)
  • As calculated above, total filtered glucose is 180, Transport maximum is 150
  • = 180-150 mg/min = 30 mg/min is the excretion

 

Educational Objective:

 

Total filtered glucose=GFR × Plasma glucose concentration

Excretion=Total filtered glucose−Total reabsorbed glucose (Transport Max.)

questions.text: A patient presents with a swelling in the groin region. A diagnosis of direct inguinal hernia is made. Weakness in which of the following structures is most likely to cause this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Conjoint tendon

 

  • A direct inguinal hernia occurs when abdominal contents herniate through a weak point in the fascia of the abdominal wall.
  • This type of hernia protrudes through the Hesselbach's triangle, which is defined by the rectus abdominis muscle medially, the inferior epigastric vessels laterally, and the inguinal ligament inferiorly.
  • The conjoint tendon, which is formed by the merging of the transversus abdominis and internal oblique muscles, makes up the main part of the medial portion of the posterior wall of the inguinal canal.
  • Weakness in the conjoint tendon is most likely to cause a direct inguinal hernia.

 

Direct Inguinal Hernia

 

  • Pathophysiology: Arises from Hesselbach’s triangle, medial to the inferior epigastric artery.
  • Mechanism: Due to weakness in the conjoint tendon.
  • Key Feature: Protrudes directly through the abdominal wall without passing through the inguinal canal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pectineal ligament: The pectineal ligament (Cooper's ligament) is a thickened band of periosteum along the pectineal line of the pubis. It is not typically involved in the development of direct inguinal hernias.

 

Option C. Reflected part of inguinal ligament: The reflected part of the inguinal ligament is a part of the external oblique aponeurosis and is not the primary structure associated with the weakness leading to direct inguinal hernias.

 

Option D. Lacunar ligament: The lacunar ligament forms the medial boundary of the femoral canal and is associated more with femoral hernias rather than inguinal hernias.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Direct inguinal hernias result from a weakness in the conjoint tendon, which forms a crucial part of the posterior wall of the inguinal canal.
  •  This anatomical weakness allows abdominal contents to protrude directly through the abdominal wall within Hesselbach’s triangle.

questions.text:
Which of the following is a criteria for making a diagnosis of an anaphylactic reaction?  (INICET MAY 2024)

  1. Swollen lips and urticaria
  2. Hypertension
  3. Breathing difficulty
  4. Persistent abdominal pain and vomiting
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 and 3

 

Anaphylactic reaction is a severe, life-threatening allergic reaction that is classified as a type I hypersensitivity reaction. This reaction involves the rapid release of histamine and other mediators from mast cells and basophils, leading to a variety of symptoms.

 

Key Criteria for Anaphylactic Reaction:

 

1. Swollen lips and urticaria: These are common manifestations of anaphylaxis due to histamine release causing increased vascular permeability and vasodilation, leading to swelling and hives.

 

3. Breathing difficulty: The release of leukotrienes and other mediators can cause bronchospasm, leading to respiratory distress and difficulty in breathing.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Hypertension

 

Anaphylactic reactions typically cause hypotension (low blood pressure) due to widespread vasodilation and increased capillary permeability, not hypertension.

 

4. Persistent abdominal pain and vomiting

 

While abdominal pain and vomiting can occur in anaphylaxis, they are not the most typical or defining features. Persistent symptoms are less commonly associated with anaphylaxis compared to the more acute and severe symptoms like swelling and breathing difficulty.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of swollen lips and urticaria along with breathing difficulty are key criteria for diagnosing an anaphylactic reaction, while hypertension and persistent abdominal pain are not typical features.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids is not formed after post-translational modification? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Selenocysteine

 

Selenocysteine is abbreviated as SeCys is the 21st human amino acid.

It is formed by co-translational modification.

 

It is seen at the active site of the following enzymes:

 

  1. Thioredoxin reductase
  2. Glutathione peroxidase, which scavenges peroxides;
  3. De-iodinase that removes iodine from thyroxine to make triiodothyronine
  4. Selenoprotein P, a glycoprotein seen in mammalian blood.

 

Replacement of Secys by Cys will lead to decreased activity of these enzymes.

Deficiency of these enzymes may be related with atherosclerosis, as these enzymes have an antioxidant function. Their concentration falls in selenium deficiency.

 

Its structure is COOH–CHNH2–CH2–SeH. It is incorporated into protein during translation process. There is a tRNA, specific to carry Secys. The codon is UGA. Biosynthesis of selenocysteine is by replacing the oxygen of serine by selenium; this is done by two steps:

 

  1. Se + ATP → Se-P + AMP + Pi
  2. Serine + Se-P → SeCys + Pi

 

The code for SeCys is UGA, which is identified by a SeCys insertion element in the mRNA, with the help of a specific elongation factor. The tRNA-Sec is first charged with serine, then it is converted into SeCys. This is then inserted into the correct position, when protein is synthesized.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Triiodothyronine (T3): Formed by post-translational modification of thyroxine (T4) through the enzymatic removal of an iodine atom.

 

Option C. Hydroxyproline: Formed by post-translational hydroxylation of proline, a process critical for the stability of collagen.

 

Option D. Hydroxylysine: Formed by post-translational hydroxylation of lysine, also important in collagen stability.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A woman presenting with symptoms of urinary tract infection was prescribed a drug that causes tendon rupture and arthropathy. What is the mechanism of action of the drug? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) DNA gyrase inhibition

 

The description of a drug causing tendon rupture and arthropathy, especially in the context of treating a urinary tract infection, points towards a fluoroquinolone antibiotic. Fluoroquinolones, such as ciprofloxacin, work by inhibiting bacterial DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV, which are essential for bacterial DNA replication and transcription.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ribosomal Inhibition: Antibiotics that inhibit ribosomes, such as macrolides, tetracyclines, and aminoglycosides, affect protein synthesis. These drugs are not typically associated with tendon rupture or arthropathy.

 

Option C. Cell Wall Synthesis Inhibition: Drugs that inhibit cell wall synthesis, like beta-lactams (penicillins, cephalosporins) and vancomycin, are not known to cause tendon rupture or arthropathy as a common side effect.

 

Option D. Inhibition of Folic Acid Synthesis: Antibiotics that inhibit folic acid synthesis, such as sulfonamides and trimethoprim, do not typically cause tendon rupture or arthropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fluoroquinolones, which inhibit DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV, are associated with serious side effects such as tendon rupture and arthropathy.

choices.text: Waxy cast
RBC cast
WBC cast
Maltese cross cast

questions.text: During rounds, you come across the urinalysis report of the 30-year-old male diagnosed with Fabry's disease. What type of urinary casts would you expect to see in the report? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Maltese cross cast

 

Maltese cross urinary casts are seen in a patient diagnosed with Fabry's disease.

 

Urine analysis in Fabry's disease may reveal oval fat bodies and birefringent glycolipid globules under polarized light showing a Maltese cross appearance.

 

 

Maltese cross birefringence has also been described in:

 

Cryptococcus neoformans, cholesterol ester storage disease, babesiosis, and in urine sediments of a patient with nephrotic syndrome and erythropoietic protoporphyria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Waxy cast: Waxy casts are typically seen in chronic kidney disease and are associated with severe tubular atrophy and stasis of urine flow. They do not exhibit a Maltese cross pattern.

 

Option B. RBC cast: RBC casts are indicative of glomerular injury, such as in glomerulonephritis, and are not associated with Fabry's disease.

 

Option C. WBC cast: WBC casts are typically seen in conditions like pyelonephritis or interstitial nephritis, where there is inflammation involving the renal tubules or interstitium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maltese cross casts in urinalysis are indicative of Fabry's disease due to the presence of glycolipid-laden renal tubular cells. These casts show a characteristic birefringent pattern under polarized light.

questions.text: The X-ray of a 5-year-old child is given below. Clinical examination, and hematological and urinary tests were normal. Which of the following is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Langerhans cell histiocytosis

 

  • The history and the provided imaging, which shows a single punched-out lytic lesion without a sclerotic rim and with a beveled edge look, point to Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH).
  • LCH is a rare disorder involving clonal proliferation of Langerhans cells, abnormal cells deriving from bone marrow and capable of migrating from skin to lymph nodes. This condition particularly affects children and can present with single or multiple lytic bone lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Multiple myeloma:  A diagnosis of multiple myeloma is made by the typical triad of symptoms, which includes a marrow plasmacytosis of more than 10%, radiologic evidence of lytic bone lesions, and the presence of serum and/or urine M component.

 

 

Option C. Metastasis: In children, metastatic lesions in the skull are uncommon and typically originate from primary neuroblastoma or sarcoma but would present with different clinical features and possibly multiple lesions.


Option D. Primary hyperparathyroidism:  Patients with this condition have high levels of the parathyroid hormone, as well as hypercalcemia, hypophosphatemia, and hypercalciuria.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Langerhans cell histiocytosis is the most probable diagnosis given the age of the child, the radiographic appearance of the skull lesion, and the absence of systemic symptoms or biochemical abnormalities typically associated with the other conditions listed.

questions.text: What test is not used for testing olfaction? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arnold stick test

 

The Arnold stick test is not a recognized method for assessing olfaction. The name does not correspond with standard or commonly used olfactory tests, which typically involve the identification or differentiation of specific odors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Smell Diskettes: These are used in screening tests for olfaction, where reusable diskettes are impregnated with different odorants. Participants are asked to identify scents from a list, often aided by illustrative questionnaires.

Option C. UPSIT: The University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test is a widely recognized and comprehensive olfactory test. It is self-administered and involves scratching odor-impregnated booklets to release smells, which the test-taker must then identify.

Option D. CC-SIT: The Cross-Cultural Smell Identification Test, a shorter form of the UPSIT, consists of 12 items and is designed for quick administration, making it practical for use in diverse populations and clinical settings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tests used for olfaction are as follows:

 

  1. Smell diskettes are used as a screening test for olfaction. Reusable diskettes are used with the application of 8 different odorants. A questionnaire with illustrations is used to score the patient.
  2. University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test (UPSIT) is a commercially available, self-administered test used to assess the function of an individual's olfactory system via smell identification. It uses microencapsulated odorants, which are released on scratching standardized odor-impregnated test booklets.
  3. The 12-item version of UPSIT, also known as the Cross-Cultural Smell Identification Test (CC-SIT), is useful for quantifying smell loss when less time is available. This test serves as a means to reliably assess olfactory function in less than 5 minutes.
  4. The Sniffin' Sticks test is a new test of nasal chemosensory performance based on pen-like odor-dispensing devices. Semi-objective assessment of the patient's olfactory performance by means of 3 subtests: threshold test, identification test and discrimination test.

 

Ref - Scott Brown 8th edition, volume 2, Page No. 1233

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents to the clinic with fatigue, pale skin, and shortness of breath. Laboratory tests reveal microcytic anemia with a high ferritin level, low transferrin saturation, and a characteristic ringed sideroblast on bone marrow biopsy. The patient’s medical history includes chronic alcohol use and previous tuberculosis treated with isoniazid. Which treatment is commonly used for managing his type of anemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Pyridoxine

 

Explanation:

 

Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) is commonly used in the treatment of sideroblastic anemia, particularly when it is due to pyridoxine-dependent enzyme deficiencies. This condition often arises from disruptions in heme synthesis, leading to the accumulation of iron within the mitochondria of red blood cell precursors, forming ringed sideroblasts. Pyridoxine acts as a cofactor for enzymes involved in heme synthesis, enhancing the production of heme and reducing mitochondrial iron accumulation. This treatment is particularly effective in cases related to genetic disorders or acquired forms due to alcohol, isoniazid, or other drugs.

 

Other Options:

 

A. Folic Acid: Folic acid is used to treat megaloblastic anemia due to folate deficiency but is not effective in managing sideroblastic anemia, as it does not address the underlying problem of disrupted heme synthesis or iron accumulation in the mitochondria.

 

C. Erythropoietin: Erythropoietin stimulates red blood cell production and is used in anemia of chronic kidney disease and other forms of anemia due to low erythropoiesis, but it does not directly address the mitochondrial iron trapping seen in sideroblastic anemia.

 

D. Iron Chelation Therapy: While iron chelation therapy is used in conditions with iron overload, it is not the primary treatment for sideroblastic anemia itself. Chelation helps manage iron toxicity rather than correcting the underlying defect in heme synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) is an effective treatment for sideroblastic anemia due to its role in heme synthesis. It aids in reducing iron accumulation in mitochondria and can improve hematologic outcomes, especially in cases related to pyridoxine-dependent enzyme deficiencies or acquired causes such as alcoholism and certain medications.

questions.text: A researcher is examining the relationship between height and weight in a specific population. She decides to utilize a cluster sampling method to streamline the data collection process. After analyzing data from four distinct clusters, each one consistently demonstrates a correlation coefficient of 0.6 between height and weight. Based on this information, what can the researcher expect about the overall correlation coefficient when combining data from all four clusters? [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Equal to 0.6

 

  • When each cluster independently shows a correlation coefficient of 0.6 between height and weight, the overall correlation coefficient for the combined data will also be 0.6.
  • This is because the correlation coefficient measures the strength and direction of a linear relationship between two variables, and consistent values across clusters will result in the same overall correlation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SCATTER/DOT DIAGRAM

 

  • Also known as ‘Correlation diagram
  • Is used to depict ‘correlation (relationship) between 2 quantitative variables
  • Vertical axis in scatter diagram: should be the dependent or the outcome variable
  • In a scatter diagram, 2 imaginary lines are drawn along the distribution of dots/ scatter.

choices.text: Acute kidney failure
Acute respiratory failure
Acute cardiac failure

questions.text: A 58-year-old male who underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) presents on the fifth postoperative day with tachypnea and hypotension. The patient is receiving continuous monitoring and treatment in the intensive care unit. Based on the clinical presentation, what is the most probable cause of the patient's symptoms, and what further diagnostic workup would be necessary? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute respiratory failure

 

Acute respiratory failure is a common postoperative complication following CABG, due to factors like atelectasis, which is a partial or complete collapse of the lung. Postoperative tachypnea and hypotension can also be driven by pulmonary issues in this setting, making acute respiratory failure the most likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Sepsis: While sepsis could cause these symptoms, the scenario lacks specific indications of infection such as fever or leukocytosis.


Option B. Acute kidney failure: This could manifest with different symptoms primarily related to fluid overload or electrolyte imbalances, not specifically tachypnea.


Option D. Acute cardiac failure: Could be considered, but the primary symptom would more typically be related to cardiac output rather than respiratory distress.

 

Educational Objective:


Recognize that acute respiratory failure is a common complication after CABG, often manifesting with tachypnea and hypotension.

choices.text: EDV and pressure curve shifts to left without change in slope
Slope changes in ESV pressure curve
End systolic volume and pressure curve shifts to left without change in slope
Slope changes in EDV and pressure curve

questions.text:
If the contractility of the heart is decreased, which of the following is seen? (INICET Nov 2021)

 

ESV: End-systolic volume

EDV: End-diastolic volume
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Slope changes in ESV pressure curve

 

A decrease in contractility of the heart can result in changes in the slope of the end-systolic pressure-volume relationship (ESV pressure curve) in addition to changes in end-systolic volume (ESV) and end-diastolic volume (EDV).

 

When contractility is decreased, the ventricle is less able to generate the same pressure for a given volume of blood, resulting in a reduced slope of the ESV pressure curve. This indicates that the heart is less efficient in ejecting blood during systole.

 

Therefore, the correct answer is B. Slope changes in ESV pressure curve. This is because the slope of the ESV pressure curve is an index of contractility, and a decrease in contractility results in a reduced slope of the curve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. is incorrect because a leftward shift of the end-diastolic pressure-volume curve without a change in slope is seen in conditions such as hypertension and aortic stenosis, where the heart has to generate greater pressure to overcome an increased afterload.

 

Option C. is incorrect because a leftward shift of the end-systolic pressure-volume curve without a change in slope is not typically seen in response to changes in contractility.

 

Option D. is incorrect because a change in the slope of the EDV pressure curve is not typically observed in response to changes in contractility.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A decrease in cardiac contractility leads to a decrease in the slope of the end-systolic pressure-volume (ESV) curve, indicating reduced efficiency in blood ejection during systole.

choices.text: Peripheral neuropathy is a common adverse effect
It is active against gram positive organisms
It has poor oral bioavailability
Major mode of elimination is renal excretion

questions.text: Which of the following statements about tedizolid is true? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. It is active against gram positive organisms

 

Tedizolid is an oxazolidinone-class antibiotic, similar to linezolid, and is primarily used to treat infections caused by gram-positive bacteria.

 

Activity Against Gram-Positive Organisms: Tedizolid is particularly effective against gram-positive pathogens, including methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and vancomycin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (VRSA). It works by inhibiting protein synthesis through binding to the 50S ribosomal subunit.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Peripheral neuropathy is a common adverse effect: Peripheral neuropathy and lactic acidosis are potential adverse effects of tedizolid, but they are not common.

 

Option C. It has poor oral bioavailability: This is incorrect. Tedizolid has very good oral bioavailability, nearly 90%, making it effective when administered orally.

 

Option D. Major mode of elimination is renal excretion: This is incorrect. Tedizolid is primarily metabolized in the liver, and renal excretion is not the major route of elimination.

 

Educational objective:

 

Tedizolid is a protein synthesis inhibitor that is primarily active against gram-positive organisms, including resistant strains like MRSA and VRSA. It has good oral bioavailability and is primarily metabolized in the liver.

 

Reference: KDT 8th/808

questions.text: Match the following parasites with their respective hosts: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-3, B-2, C-4, D-1

 

  • Diphyllobothrium latum: Humans (definitive host), Cyclops (first intermediate host), and Fish (second intermediate host).
  • Paragonimus westermani: Humans (definitive host), Snail (first intermediate host), Crayfish and Crab (second intermediate host).
  • Brugia malayi: Humans (definitive host), Mansonia mosquito (intermediate host).
  • Fasciola hepatica: Sheep and Humans (definitive hosts), Snail (first intermediate host), Aquatic vegetation (second intermediate host).

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: A patient presented with an enlarged inguinal lymph node. Which of the following is the most likely primary cause? (NEET PG 2020 )
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Anal cancer

 

Enlargement of the inguinal lymph node is most commonly caused by the anal canal below the dentate line (which marks the border between the anal canal and rectum) goes into the inguinal lymph nodes. As a result, anal cancer occurring below the dentate line can lead to the enlargement of the inguinal lymph nodes.

 

However, lymphatics from the anal canal above the dentate line (i.e., the rectum) drain into the internal iliac lymph nodes through superior rectal lymphatics.

 

Anal Cancer:  A malignancy that originates in the anal canal or anal margin.

 

  • Lymphatic Spread: The primary lymphatic drainage from the anal canal is to the inguinal lymph nodes. Hence, an enlarged inguinal lymph node can indicate the spread of a tumor from the anal region.
  • Clinical Relevance: Patients with anal cancer may present with anal bleeding, pain, or itching. Inguinal lymph node enlargement is an important sign to check for, as it indicates lymphatic spread.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Testicular Cancer: Malignancy that originates within the testes.

 

  • Lymphatic Spread: The primary lymphatic drainage of the testes is to the para-aortic lymph nodes. Therefore, testicular tumors typically spread first to these nodes.
  • Clinical Relevance: While testicular cancer can metastasize to the inguinal lymph nodes, it's an unusual pathway and typically occurs after a surgical procedure in the groin, which can disrupt the typical lymphatic drainage patterns.

 

Option C. Sigmoid Colon Cancer: Malignancy that arises from the sigmoid portion of the colon.

 

  • Lymphatic Spread: The primary lymphatic drainage of the sigmoid colon is to the colic nodes and then to the inferior mesenteric nodes.
  • Clinical Relevance: Inguinal lymph node enlargement is not a typical early site of metastasis for sigmoid colon cancer. More common metastatic sites include the liver and lungs.

 

Option D. Prostate Cancer: Malignancy that originates within the prostate gland.

 

  • Lymphatic Spread: The primary lymphatic drainage of the prostate is to the internal iliac lymph nodes and then to the external iliac nodes.
  • Clinical Relevance: While it's possible for prostate cancer to metastasize to the inguinal nodes, it's not the typical pattern of lymphatic spread. Symptoms of prostate cancer include urinary frequency, nocturia, and difficulty starting and maintaining a steady stream of urine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anal cancer is a primary malignancy associated with the enlargement of inguinal lymph nodes due to its anatomical and lymphatic relationship with the anal canal below the dentate line. Recognizing this link is crucial for correct diagnosis and treatment planning.

questions.text: A young man came to the medical OPD with complaints of early morning backache and stiffness, which improves on exercise, and persistent red eyes. On examination, lung expansion was less than 3 cm. X-ray is shown in the image given below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ankylosing spondylitis

 

Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) is a chronic inflammatory disease that primarily affects the spine and sacroiliac joints, leading to pain and stiffness. The hallmark feature of AS is inflammatory back pain, which is characterized by pain and stiffness that are worse in the morning and improve with exercise. The persistent red eyes are indicative of anterior uveitis, a common extra-articular manifestation of AS.

 

The reduced lung expansion (less than 3 cm) points towards involvement of the thoracic spine, leading to restrictive lung disease due to reduced chest wall mobility. The X-ray image shows characteristic changes of AS, including syndesmophytes and the "bamboo spine" appearance, which result from the ossification of ligaments and entheses (where tendons and ligaments attach to the bone).

 

Bamboo spine

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Paget's disease: This condition is characterized by abnormal bone remodeling but does not typically present with inflammatory back pain or extra-articular manifestations such as uveitis.

 

Option C. Healed tuberculosis: While tuberculosis can affect the spine (Pott's disease), it does not present with the classic inflammatory back pain or the characteristic radiographic changes seen in AS.

 

Option D. Osteopetrosis: This is a rare genetic disorder that leads to increased bone density and brittleness but does not present with the clinical and radiographic features of AS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ankylosing spondylitis should be suspected in young patients with inflammatory back pain that improves with exercise, reduced lung expansion, and extra-articular manifestations such as uveitis. The "bamboo spine" on X-ray is a characteristic finding in advanced cases of AS.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female consumed a white colored rodenticide powder and presents with a potassium level of 2.5 mEq/L. She has irregular pulse and muscle paralysis. ECG shows multiple ventricular ectopic beats. What is the suspected poison? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Barium Carbonate

 

Barium carbonate poisoning is characterized by severe hypokalemia (low potassium levels), which leads to symptoms such as muscle paralysis and irregular pulse. The ECG changes, such as multiple ventricular ectopic beats, are also indicative of hypokalemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aluminum Phosphide: This poison releases phosphine gas in the stomach, which inhibits cytochrome C oxidase and causes oxidative stress, leading to cytotoxic effects. The main symptom is profound hypotension, not hypokalemia.

 

Option B. Zinc Phosphide: Similar to aluminum phosphide, zinc phosphide also releases phosphine gas and causes oxidative stress and cytochrome C oxidase inhibition, leading to cytotoxic effects and profound hypotension, not hypokalemia.

 

Option D. Warfarin: Warfarin is an anticoagulant that causes bleeding and bruising with an elevated PT/INR, but it does not cause hypokalemia or the associated symptoms described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypokalemia with symptoms such as muscle paralysis, irregular pulse, and ECG changes like ventricular ectopic beats strongly suggest poisoning with barium carbonate.

questions.text: The structure passing through the central tendon of the diaphragm is: (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Inferior vena cava

 

Explanation:

 

The inferior vena cava is a major vein that returns deoxygenated blood from the lower half of the body to the right atrium of the heart. The IVC passes through the diaphragm via the caval opening, which is situated to the right of the central tendon. This opening allows the IVC to move between the thoracic and abdominal cavities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oesophagus: The esophagus passes through an opening in the diaphragm called the esophageal hiatus, which is located just to the left of the central tendon. This allows the esophagus to traverse from the thoracic cavity to the abdominal cavity.

 

Option B. Aorta: The descending (thoracic) aorta carries oxygenated blood from the heart to the lower parts of the body. It passes through the diaphragm via the aortic hiatus, which is posterior to the central tendon. The aorta then continues its descent into the abdominal cavity.

 

Option D. Sympathetic Chain: The sympathetic chain, also known as the sympathetic trunk or sympathetic ganglia, consists of a series of ganglia connected by nerve fibers. It runs vertically along each side of the vertebral column and is not directly associated with the diaphragm or its central tendon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diaphragm has three anatomic openings: the aortic hiatus (T12), the esophageal hiatus (T10), and the caval foramen (T8)

 

  • The inferior vena cava passes through the central tendon of the diaphragm from the caval foramen.
  • Esophagus passes through the esophageal hiatus.
  • Aorta passes through the aortic hiatus.

 

Sympathetic chain passes through the minor apertures crossing the crura of the diaphragm.

questions.text: The histopathology picture below is suggestive of? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pemphigus vulgaris

 

The given slide shows a row of tombstones' appearance, which is classically seen in Pemphigus vulgaris.

 

The production of antibodies, specifically those against Desmoglein 3, is seen in Pemphigus vulgaris. Desmoglein 1 antibodies are also occasionally associated. Usually, the antibodies are IgG antibodies. The skin and mucosa's basal and suprabasal layers contain the majority of Desmoglein 3. Hemidesmosomes help in connecting basal layer to underlying dermo-epidermal junction, in pemphigus vulgaris there are no antibodies against Hemidesmosomes, so the basal layer remains attached to the underlying dermo-epidermal junction giving the classical Row of tombstones appearance.

 

The patients, therefore, present with flaccid bullae over the skin and due to Desmoglein 3 involvement, mucosal involvement can also be seen. Oral mucosa is commonly affected. Other areas where ulceration can be seen are conjunctiva, nasopharynx, larynx, etc.

 

Cutaneous lesions are more common over the scalp, face, neck, upper chest, and back.

 

Biopsy: The basal layer remains adherent to the basement membrane and gives the resemblance to a row of tombstones.

 

 

IMAGE of row of tombstones appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Psoriasis vulgaris:

 

  • This is an autoimmune disease characterized by hyperproliferation of keratinocytes leading to thickened, scaly plaques.
  • Histologically, it shows parakeratosis (retention of nuclei in the stratum corneum), elongation of rete ridges, and a neutrophilic infiltrate (Munro's microabscesses) as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • The tombstone appearance is not a feature of psoriasis.

 

Option B. Leishmaniasis:

 

  • It's a parasitic infection caused by the Leishmania species.
  • Histologically, it is characterized by macrophages containing the parasite (Leishman-Donovan bodies) in the dermis as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • The tombstone appearance is not seen in leishmaniasis.

 

Option C. Mycosis fungoides:

 

  • This is a type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma.
  • Histologically, there is an atypical lymphocytic infiltrate in the epidermis (epidermotropism), and the formation of Pautrier's microabscesses (collections of lymphocytes in the epidermis) as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • It does not exhibit a tombstone appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The histopathology image suggests Pemphigus vulgaris, which is characterized by intraepidermal blistering due to acantholysis, or separation of keratinocytes, as a result of autoantibody attack on desmosomal proteins.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition Chapter 50 Page no 50.1-50.8

questions.text: Maternal infection that may lead to teratogenic effect is: [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) All of the above

 

Explanation

 

All listed infections—Chickenpox, Rubella, and CMV (Cytomegalovirus)—can potentially lead to teratogenic effects if a mother contracts them during pregnancy. Here's a brief explanation of how each can impact fetal development:

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Chickenpox: Infection in early pregnancy can lead to congenital varicella syndrome, which includes skin scarring, limb abnormalities, and neurologic disorders.

 

Option B. Rubella: Known for its teratogenic potential if contracted in the first trimester; can cause congenital rubella syndrome, leading to cataracts, deafness, heart defects, and neurological damage.

 

Option C. CMV: The most common viral cause of congenital infections leading to developmental disabilities, including hearing loss, vision loss, and neurodevelopmental disorders.

 

Educational objective :

 

Maternal infection that may lead to teratogenic effect is : TORCH infection

 

  • Toxoplasmosis
  • Other (includes infections such as Syphilis, Varicella-Zoster, Parvovirus B19, and Zika virus)
  • Rubella
  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV)
  • Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV)

 

Note – Now, also includes – Treponema pallidum, HIV, Hep. B viruses

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient diagnosed with Wilson's disease presents with symptoms of hepatomegaly, neurological disturbances, and a distinctive golden-brown ring around the cornea. Laboratory tests confirm decreased serum ceruloplasmin and elevated liver copper content. Given the abnormal copper metabolism in Wilson's disease, which substance is typically found to be decreased in the patient's urine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. 3-methylhistidine

 

Explanation:

 

In Wilson's disease, 3-methylhistidine levels are typically decreased in the urine. Wilson's disease is a genetic disorder caused by a mutation affecting copper transport, leading to copper accumulation in the liver, brain, and other tissues. This copper buildup disrupts normal metabolic processes, including the excretion of certain amino acids such as 3-methylhistidine. The reduced excretion of 3-methylhistidine in urine is associated with the overall disturbance in protein metabolism due to copper toxicity in the liver, affecting the breakdown and release of this compound into the urine.

 

Other Options:

 

A. Urea: Urea is a major end product of protein metabolism and is typically excreted normally or increased in urine in liver dysfunctions due to protein catabolism. It is not specifically decreased in Wilson's disease.

 

C. Creatinine: Creatinine levels in urine are influenced by kidney function and muscle mass, and its excretion is not specifically decreased in Wilson's disease. Creatinine is commonly used as a marker for renal function rather than copper metabolism.

 

D. Glucose: Glucose in urine, or glucosuria, typically indicates issues with renal glucose reabsorption or uncontrolled diabetes. It is not decreased in Wilson’s disease, as glucose excretion is not directly affected by copper accumulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wilson's disease is characterized by impaired copper excretion leading to its accumulation in various tissues, causing hepatic, neurological, and ocular manifestations. The disease affects protein metabolism, notably decreasing the urinary excretion of 3-methylhistidine. Understanding the metabolic disruptions in Wilson's disease is critical for diagnosing and managing this genetic condition effectively, highlighting the importance of recognizing specific biochemical markers associated with copper toxicity.

choices.text: To induce anesthesia and relax muscles
To prevent memory loss after the ECT

questions.text: A patient undergoing ECT for his severe depression was given thiopentone and succinylcholine. The purpose of these medications was to? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) To induce anesthesia and relax muscles

 

During electroconvulsive therapy (ECT), thiopentone is used to induce anesthesia, ensuring that the patient is unconscious and doesn't experience pain during the procedure. Succinylcholine is a muscle relaxant, used to prevent forceful and uncontrolled muscle contractions that can occur during the ECT, thus reducing the risk of injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To bring calming effect: Neither thiopentone nor succinylcholine is specifically used for their calming effects in the context of ECT.

 

Option B. To produce mood elevation: The medications aren't administered to produce mood elevation. The therapeutic effect of ECT itself is what aids in mood elevation.

 

Option D. To prevent memory loss after the ECT: Memory loss can be a side effect of ECT, but the drugs mentioned are not given to prevent this effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thiopentone and succinylcholine are administered prior to ECT to induce anesthesia and relax muscles, respectively, to ensure patient safety and comfort during the procedure.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 1069.

questions.text: Which of the following would be prescribed for simple myopic astigmatism?  (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. -1.00 DC X 180 degree

 

  • The correct prescription for simple myopic astigmatism is -1.00 DC × 180 degrees.
  • Simple myopic astigmatism means that one principal meridian of the eye is in focus on the retina, while the other principal meridian is in front of the retina.
  • There are three components to the prescription of glasses for astigmatism: 
    1. The power of the spherical component (convex or concave dioptre sphere),
    2. The power of the cylinder (convex or concave dioptre cylinder),
    3. The axis (orientation) of the cylinder.

 

For example: -1.00 DC × 180 degree

 

This prescription indicates that the individual has simple astigmatism, which means one meridian of the eye is in focus while the other is not. In this case, the unfocused meridian is myopic (nearsighted) and requires correction with a concave cylinder lens. The strength of the cylinder lens is -1.00 diopters (DC). The axis of the cylinder is oriented at 180 degrees, which represents the meridian that is most affected by astigmatism.

 

Types of astigmatism:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. +1.00 DS: This represents a convex spherical lens for hypermetropia (farsightedness) and is not used for astigmatism correction.

 

Option C. -1.00 DS: This represents a concave spherical lens for simple myopia (nearsightedness) but does not correct astigmatism.

 

Option D. -1.00 DS -1.00 DC X 180 degree: This represents a prescription for compound myopic astigmatism, where both meridians are myopic, one corrected by the spherical component and the other by the cylindrical component.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Simple myopic astigmatism requires correction with a cylindrical lens that corrects the myopic meridian, typically specified with the cylinder power and the axis. The correct prescription for simple myopic astigmatism in this case is -1.00 DC X 180 degrees.

choices.text: Calcium channel blockers
Alpha methyl dopa

questions.text: A 35-year woman is a chronic hypertensive. She visits the clinic for preconception counseling. Which of the following anti-hypertensives need to be stopped prior to conception? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ACE inhibitors

 

Explanation:

 

ACE Inhibitors in Pregnancy:

 

  • ACE inhibitors are contraindicated during pregnancy due to their association with significant fetal complications.
  • They can cause oligohydramnios, fetal growth restriction, renal dysgenesis, and even fetal death.
  • Angiotensin Receptor Blockers (ARBs) are also contraindicated for similar reasons.
  • It is essential for women on these medications to discontinue them prior to conception and switch to safer alternatives.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Calcium channel blockers: These are generally considered safe during pregnancy and do not need to be discontinued.

 

Option B. Alpha methyl dopa: This is a safe and commonly used antihypertensive during pregnancy.

 

Option D. Labetalol: Labetalol is another safe option during pregnancy and is frequently used for managing hypertension in pregnant women.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ACE inhibitors and Angiotensin Receptor Blockers are contraindicated during pregnancy and should be discontinued prior to conception.

 

Ref: Page no 401, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Vesicular lesions due to Herpes simplex infection

questions.text: Topical steroids are most effective in: (AIIMS Nov 2019
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Eczematous dermatitis.

 

Topical steroids are the drug of choice in the treatment of eczematous dermatitis.

 

  • Topical steroids are anti-inflammatory medications that are highly effective in treating eczematous dermatitis, which is characterized by inflammation, redness, and itching of the skin.
  • They work by reducing inflammation and suppressing the immune response in the skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dermal atrophy: Dermal atrophy is actually a side effect of prolonged or inappropriate use of topical steroids, not a condition that is treated with them. It is thinning of the skin which can lead to transparency, easy bruising, and other skin changes as shown below.

 

 

Option C. Vesicular lesions due to Herpes simplex infection: Topical steroids are contraindicated in herpes simplex infections because they can exacerbate the condition by suppressing the local immune response, which is necessary to control viral infections.

 

 

Herpes labialis: Vesicular lesions due to Herpes simplex

 

Option D. Rosacea: Topical steroids may temporarily reduce inflammation associated with rosacea, but their use is generally avoided as they can lead to a worsening of the condition over time, particularly by exacerbating flushing and potentially leading to a condition known as steroid-induced rosacea.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Topical steroids are effective in treating eczematous dermatitis due to their anti-inflammatory properties, but they should not be used for conditions like herpes simplex infections or rosacea, and can cause dermal atrophy if used inappropriately.

 

Ref - Fitzpatrick’s Dermatology, 9th edition page number 377

choices.text: Presence of a mass in the periumbilical region
Brilliant transillumination when a light is shone through the mass
Mobility of the mass perpendicular to the mesentery attachment line
Positive fluctuation observed when the mass is pressed

questions.text: Identify the true statement about the Tillaux sign? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mobility of the mass perpendicular to the mesentery attachment line

 

Tillaux sign is seen in presence of mesenteric cyst, which shows mobility perpendicular to line of mesenteric attachment.

 

The Tillaux sign refers to the observation that a tumor arising from mesentry, typically a mesenteric cyst will move in a direction perpendicular to the line of mesenteric attachment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Presence of a mass in the periumbilical region: While the presence of a mass can be indicative of many conditions, the Tillaux sign specifically refers to the mobility of a mass in relation to the mesentery attachment, not merely the presence of a mass.

 

Option B. Brilliance of transillumination when a light is shone through the mass: This describes the positive transillumination test that might be observed in cystic masses like hydroceles or  superficial cysts with clear fluid like ranula.

 

Option D. Positive fluctuation observed when the mass is pressed: This refers to a fluctuation test, where pressing on one side of a fluid-filled mass results in a palpable bulge or movement on the opposite side. This indicates the presence of fluid within the mass but isn't related to the Tillaux sign.

 

In summary, the Tillaux sign helps in the clinical assessment of abdominal masses, with the mass's mobility providing clues about its origin and location in relation to the mesentery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tillaux's sign is positive when a mesenteric cyst is present, and the mass or swelling is mobile perpendicular to the mesentery attachment line. Mesenteric cysts are typically found in the small intestine (60%) or colon (40%) and can be classified as chylolymphatic (the most common type), enterogenous, urogenital remnant, or dermoid. These cysts are commonly found in adults and are characterized by a painless abdominal swelling with physical signs (Tillaux triad) such as a fluctuant swelling near the umbilicus, a mass that moves freely in a plane perpendicular to the attachment of the mesentery (known as Tillaux's sign), and the presence of a zone of resonance around the cyst.

 

Tillaux triad of mesenteric cyst:

 

  1. Soft fluctuant periumbilical lump
  2. Movement perpendicular to mesenteric attachment
  3. Zone of resonance around the lump

questions.text: A small child was playing with her maid where she rotated her by holding from arms. Immediately after, the child started crying. On examination, her forearm was pronated. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pulled elbow

 

  • History of traction on elbow with forearm pronated is classical of pulled elbow.

 

PULLED ELBOW/NURSE MAID’S ELBOW

 

  • It is subluxation of radial head or more accurately subluxation of the annular (orbicular) ligament which slips up over the head of radius into the radio-capitellar joint.

 

 

  • Mechanism of Injury: Traction to elbow.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Maximum incidence in 1-4 years of age group.
    • The child holds the elbow in slight flexion with the forearm pronated.
    • X-rays are normal.
  • Treatment:
    • Reduced by flexing the elbow to 90° and rapidly and firmly rotating the forearm into full supination on outdoor basis without anaesthesia. 
    • Immobilization is not necessary.
    • Supination is a gravity-assisted movement and pulled elbow may be reduced spontaneously by gravity, but this may take time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dislocation of elbow. Elbow Dislocations in the pediatric population usually occur in older children (10-15 years) and can be associated with elbow fractures such as medial epicondyle fractures. Male: female = 3:1. Very rare in younger children < 3 years old. Mechanism of injury is fall on an outstretched hand. Symptoms include painful and swollen elbow, attempts at motion are painful and restricted. On physical examination, the elbow is held in flexion, forearm appears to be shortened from the anterior and posterior view. On palpation, distal humerus creates a fullness within the antecubital fossa. Radiographs shows loss of radiocapitellar and ulnohumeral relationship but maintained radial and ulnar relationship. Treatment is usually closed reduction and brief immobilization for 1-2 weeks. 

 

 

Option C. Fracture head of radius. Radial head fractures are common injuries and may occur in association with dislocation of the elbow. In children, radial neck fractures are more common than radial head fractures. Classically, the head of radius should not be excised in children because it will interfere with the synchronous growth of radius and ulna, producing wrist and elbow deformity. It may lead to proximal radial migration and subluxation of inferior radio-ulnar joint, weakness of extremity and discomfort in distal radioulnar joint with heavy activities, and may produce cubitus valgus deformity.

 

 

Option D. Fracture coronoid process. Coronoid Fractures are traumatic elbow fractures that are generally pathognomonic for an episode of elbow instability. The patient presents with elbow deformity & swelling, elbow/forearm/wrist pain. On inspection & palpation, there is varus or valgus deformity, ecchymosis & swelling, and diffuse tenderness. The treatment involves brief immobilization, followed by early range of motion. 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

History of traction on elbow with forearm in pronation in a child < 4 years of age is a classical feature of pulled elbow.

questions.text: Identify the surgical instrument shown in the image: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mixter forceps

 

Mixter forceps is used to clamp the blood vessels and prevent blood loss and pass ligatures and dissect pedicles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adson's forceps: Adson's forceps are used in surgery to manipulate soft tissues such as fascia and skin during suturing.

 

 

Option B. Kocher's forceps: Kocher's forceps is used to clamp the blood vessels and prevent blood loss. It has 2 x 1 teeth at the tip.

 

 

Option D. Rampley forceps: Rampley forceps are used in general surgery to hold swabs and sponges or to grasp tissue. It has a fenestrated tip.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with poorly controlled type 1 diabetes presents to the emergency room with symptoms of fatigue, weight loss, and increased thirst. The patient's condition is indicative of a low insulin-to-glucagon ratio. Which of the following conditions is not typically observed in this state?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Glycogen storage

 

Explanation:

 

Glycogen storage is not typically observed in a low insulin-to-glucagon ratio because this state favors the breakdown of stored energy rather than its accumulation. Insulin is necessary for promoting the synthesis and storage of glycogen in the liver and muscle tissues. When insulin levels are low and glucagon is predominant, the body shifts towards mobilizing stored nutrients, resulting in increased glycogenolysis (breakdown of glycogen), gluconeogenesis (production of glucose from non-carbohydrate sources), and ketogenesis (production of ketone bodies from fatty acids). These processes provide energy to the body during fasting or insulin deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

A. Glycogenolysis: Glycogenolysis is the breakdown of glycogen into glucose, which is stimulated by a low insulin-to-glucagon ratio. This process helps maintain blood glucose levels during fasting or insulin deficiency.

 

 

B. Ketogenesis: Ketogenesis is the production of ketone bodies from fatty acids, commonly seen in low insulin states as the body shifts to alternative energy sources. This process is enhanced when insulin levels are insufficient to suppress lipolysis.

 

C. Gluconeogenesis: Gluconeogenesis is the synthesis of glucose from non-carbohydrate precursors such as amino acids and lactate. This process is activated in a low insulin-to-glucagon ratio, ensuring a continuous supply of glucose during periods of low carbohydrate intake or insulin deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a low insulin-to-glucagon ratio, the body focuses on breaking down stored nutrients to provide energy, promoting glycogenolysis, gluconeogenesis, and ketogenesis while inhibiting processes like glycogen storage, which requires high insulin levels. Understanding these metabolic shifts is crucial in managing conditions like diabetes, where insulin deficiency plays a significant role.

questions.text: A pharmaceutical company is in the early stages of developing a new antihypertensive medication. They are planning to conduct several phases of clinical trials to assess different aspects of the drug. As part of this process, the research team is set to embark on Phase 1 of the trial. In the context of clinical trial phases, what is the primary objective of this initial phase? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Safety 

 

  • Phase 1 of clinical trials is critically important as it marks the first introduction of a new drug into human subjects.
  • The primary focus during this phase is to evaluate the safety of the drug.

 

Key elements assessed in Phase 1 include:

 

  • Safety & Non-toxicity.
  • Maximum Tolerated Dose (MTD.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Webbing of hands and toes are associated with risk of visceral anomalies
Noonan syndrome is more associated with cardiac defects
Absence of neck webbing is associated with higher risk of coarctation of aorta
Webbing of neck is associated with higher risk of cardiac anomalies

questions.text: Which amongst the following is true about Turner's syndrome? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Webbing of neck is associated with higher risk of cardiac anomalies

 

In Turner's syndrome, webbing of the neck is associated with a higher risk of cardiac anomalies.

 

Turner syndrome results from complete or partial monosomy of the X chromosome and is characterized primarily by hypogonadism in phenotypic females. It is the most common sex chromosome abnormality in females.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Webbing of hands and toes are associated with risk of visceral anomalies: Webbing of hands and toes is not specifically associated with Turner syndrome, nor is it a marker for visceral anomalies. Webbing or syndactyly is more commonly seen in other congenital conditions and does not relate directly to the risk of cardiac anomalies in Turner syndrome.

 

Option B. Noonan syndrome is more associated with cardiac defects: While Noonan syndrome does indeed have a high association with cardiac defects, the question pertains specifically to Turner syndrome. Noonan syndrome and Turner syndrome have some overlapping features, but Noonan syndrome is a distinct genetic disorder that is not related to the X chromosome abnormalities seen in Turner syndrome.

 

Option C. Absence of neck webbing is associated with higher risk of coarctation of aorta: This statement is incorrect. In Turner syndrome, the presence, not the absence, of neck webbing is associated with a higher risk of coarctation of the aorta and other cardiac anomalies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Turner syndrome, the presence of neck webbing is significantly associated with an increased risk of cardiac anomalies, particularly coarctation of the aorta and bicuspid aortic valve.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 8th edition, Pg no 318-319

choices.text: Deficiency of CD4 T lymphocytes
MHC class II deficiency on lymphocytes
MHC class I deficiency on lymphocytes

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with bare lymphocytic disease. In this patient, graft vs host reaction does not occur due to: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) MHC class II deficiency on lymphocytes

 

 

In BLS 2, the lack of MHC class II expression on lymphocytes means that CD4+ T cells are severely reduced or absent. CD4+ T cells are crucial for initiating and regulating immune responses, including the graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) reaction, where donor immune cells attack the recipient's body. The deficiency of MHC class II molecules, and consequently the absence of CD4+ T cells, prevents GVHD from occurring in patients with BLS 2.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Complement deficiency: While complement deficiency can lead to immune system problems, it does not directly prevent GVHD. GVHD is primarily driven by T cell responses, particularly CD4+ T cells.

 

Option B. Deficiency of CD4 T lymphocytes: This is a consequence of MHC class II deficiency rather than a cause. The absence of MHC class II molecules leads to a lack of CD4+ T cells.

 

Option D. MHC class I deficiency on lymphocytes: This occurs in BLS 1 and leads to a deficiency in CD8+ T cells, not CD4+ T cells. While this impacts immune function, it does not directly prevent GVHD, which is primarily mediated by CD4+ T cells.

 

Educational Objective:


In patients with Bare Lymphocyte Syndrome type 2 (BLS 2), the absence of MHC class II molecules on lymphocytes results in a lack of CD4+ T cells, preventing graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) from occurring.

choices.text: Mitochondrial DNA is inherited equally from both parents.
Mitochondrial DNA has a low mutation rate compared to nuclear DNA.
Mitochondrial DNA is circular and primarily inherited from the mother.
All proteins required for mitochondrial function are encoded by mitochondrial DNA.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to a genetic counseling clinic due to concerns about her family history of muscle weakness and exercise intolerance, she wants to know more about the potential genetic risks to her children. Which of the following statements is true regarding the mitochondrial genome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Mitochondrial DNA is circular and primarily inherited from the mother.

 

Explanation:

 

Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is circular and maternally inherited, meaning it is passed down from the mother to her offspring. This inheritance pattern occurs because mitochondria are located in the cytoplasm of the egg, whereas sperm contributes minimal, if any, mitochondria to the zygote. The mtDNA contains 37 genes that encode 13 essential protein subunits of the electron transport chain, along with 2 ribosomal RNAs and 22 tRNAs. However, most mitochondrial proteins are encoded by nuclear DNA and synthesized in the cytoplasm.

 

Other Options:

 

A. Mitochondrial DNA is inherited equally from both parents: This is incorrect as mitochondrial DNA is inherited almost exclusively from the mother due to the contribution of cytoplasmic content from the egg during fertilization, with paternal mitochondria being degraded.

 

B. Mitochondrial DNA has a low mutation rate compared to nuclear DNA: This statement is false; mtDNA has a higher mutation rate than nuclear DNA, approximately 5-10 times higher, making it more susceptible to mutations due to its proximity to reactive oxygen species generated by the electron transport chain.

 

D. All proteins required for mitochondrial function are encoded by mitochondrial DNA: This is incorrect. Although mtDNA encodes some key proteins involved in the electron transport chain, most mitochondrial proteins are encoded by nuclear DNA and imported into the mitochondria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitochondrial DNA is maternally inherited, circular, and has a high mutation rate compared to nuclear DNA. It encodes only a small number of proteins essential for mitochondrial function, while the majority of mitochondrial proteins are encoded by nuclear DNA. Understanding the unique inheritance pattern and vulnerability of mtDNA helps in diagnosing mitochondrial disorders and managing the risks associated with these genetic conditions.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old chronic smoker presents to the OPD with complaints of shortness of breath and cough. A mass is noted at the lower lobe periphery of the lung. A diagnosis of lung adenocarcinoma is made. What will be the biopsy finding? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Thyroid transcription factor-1
  2. P40
  3. Napsin A
  4. Chromogranin
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 3

 

In the context of lung adenocarcinoma, particularly in a chronic smoker presenting with a peripheral lung mass, specific markers on the biopsy can confirm the diagnosis.

 

1. Thyroid transcription factor-1 (TTF-1): TTF-1 is a nuclear transcription factor commonly expressed in lung adenocarcinoma and is used as a diagnostic marker to differentiate primary lung adenocarcinoma from other types of lung cancer.

 

3. Napsin A: Napsin A is another marker often expressed in lung adenocarcinoma, associated with the protein's role in the proteolytic processing of surfactant precursors in the lung.

 

These markers are both used to identify lung adenocarcinoma, particularly in cases where the tumor presents in the lung periphery.

 

Other options:

 

2. P40: P40 is a marker associated with squamous cell carcinoma of the lung, not adenocarcinoma. Its presence would suggest a different subtype of lung cancer.

 

4. Chromogranin: Chromogranin is a marker used in neuroendocrine tumors, such as small cell lung cancer, and is not typically found in lung adenocarcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Ultrasound showing streak ovaries and a small uterus
Ultrasound showing hepatomegaly with altered echotexture

questions.text: A 12-year girl is brought to the OPD by her mother. She is concerned that she is shorter than her peers. On examination there is ptosis on the right side, shield like chest and a webbed neck. On evaluation, which of the following is the most definitive finding? (NEET PG 2021 )
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ultrasound showing streak ovaries and a small uterus

 

Explanation:

 

Turner Syndrome:

 

  • Turner syndrome is a chromosomal disorder affecting females, characterized by the absence of all or part of one X chromosome (45,XO).
  • It presents with several distinct clinical features.

 

Clinical Features of Turner Syndrome:

 

  • Short stature: Typically shorter than peers, often the first noticeable symptom.
  • Primary amenorrhea: Due to streak gonads (non-functioning ovaries).
  • Shield-like chest: Broad chest with widely spaced nipples.
  • Webbed neck: Excess skin folds running from the tops of the shoulders to the sides of the neck.
  • Ptosis: Drooping of the upper eyelid, can be unilateral or bilateral.
  • Cardiac defects: Commonly coarctation of the aorta, though ventricular septal defects (VSD) can also occur but are less common.
  • Renal anomalies: Such as horseshoe kidney or a single kidney.
  • Other features: Low-set ears, high-arched palate, arms that turn outward at the elbows, narrow and turned-up fingernails and toenails, low hairline at the back of the head, receding or small lower jaw.

 

Ultrasound Findings:

 

  • The presence of streak ovaries (underdeveloped ovaries) and a small uterus are typical findings in Turner syndrome, leading to primary amenorrhea and infertility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ECHO shows VSD: While Turner syndrome can involve congenital heart defects, the most common cardiac anomalies are coarctation of the aorta and bicuspid aortic valve, not ventricular septal defect (VSD).

 

Option C. Ultrasound showing hepatomegaly with altered echotexture: This is not typically associated with Turner syndrome. Hepatomegaly might suggest liver disease or metabolic disorders, which are not characteristic of Turner syndrome.

 

Option D. Ultrasound showing single kidney: Renal anomalies can occur in Turner syndrome, such as a horseshoe kidney or a single kidney, but the primary findings expected include streak ovaries and a small uterus which are more specific for Turner syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Turner syndrome is characterized by a 45,XO genotype, primary amenorrhea, short stature, and distinctive physical features such as a webbed neck and shield-like chest. Ultrasound typically shows streak ovaries and a small uterus.

 

Ref: Page no 411, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: For the prevention of typhoid most important step is immunization
Proper disposal of feces, safe water supply, and personal hygiene is more important than immunization
Resistance to drugs in typhoid is less severe than that of TB
Person to person transmission is present in 10% of cases

questions.text: During a community health education session, an MBBS student is discussing the prevention of Typhoid Fever. Which of the following statements best captures the primary measures for preventing the transmission of Typhoid in the community? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Proper disposal of feces, safe water supply, personal hygiene is more important than immunization

 

  • The control of typhoid fever must be through improved sanitation and domestic/ personal hygiene.
  • Complementary approaches to prevention include immunization which is the only specific preventive measure likely to provide highest benefit for the money spent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. For the prevention of typhoid most important step is immunization: Incorrect. While important, immunization is not the most critical step compared to improving sanitation and hygiene.

 

Option C. Resistance to drugs in typhoid is less severe than that of TB: Incorrect. This statement is unrelated to primary prevention measures for typhoid.

 

Option D. Person to person transmission is present in 10% of cases: Incorrect. Person-to-person transmission is not a significant mode of transmission for typhoid compared to the ingestion of contaminated food or water.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The primary measures for preventing the transmission of Typhoid Fever in the community include proper disposal of feces, a safe water supply, and personal hygiene.
  • These measures are more important than immunization for controlling the spread of the disease.
